“I went to so much trouble to get myself ready for the man, I got all worked up and excited, and then the poor boy can barely endure a minute of my attention,” she sighed, “And just as I’m getting into it, he finished prematurely. What’s a girl to do?”

“You’re as bad as Thera,” I laughed.

“Please,” she said, taken aback, “I’m much worse, Thera might have her little Verridisiac potion that she and Abis drink by the gallon whenever they’re together, but I’ve got enough erotic spells to fill a small library.”

She looked at me out of the corner of one eye, smirking, “Maybe you and I can do some magical research some time.”

I was particularly conscious of Minki sitting next to me, as I did my best to avoid rising to Halea’s comment.

I was expecting a graceful, possibly even Wuxiaesque, fight between two Mages as skilled as Victorina and Diova. That is not what happened.

Diova opened the match with the same high flying leap as before, and again he launched a massive cloud of tiny sparks to land around his opponent, who in this case, was Victorina. In some ways Victorina mirrored the strategy of Diova’s first opponent, as she spent her first moments by casting some defensive spells. She finished much more quickly though, and already had her defences in place as the sparks started to rain down towards her. Her next spell, just as the sparks landed about her, was a Water Jet. She spun in a quick circle, soaking the ground around her. It didn’t stop the series of tiny explosions as the sparks landed, but it did prevent the sparks from catching the grass on fire.

Diova landed just after the sparks did, slightly outside of Victorina’s pool, and threw a Lightning Bolt. The bolt struck Victorina’s shield, and a spider web of bright blue lines shot out from around Victorina’s feet.

Halea inhaled sharply, and I cocked an eyebrow at her.

“The water might have been a mistake,” she said, and Victorina ignored Diova’s second bolt, and focused on a different spell, “It keeps down the fire, but that’s not nearly as big a problem as those Lighting Bolts will be if she loses her shield.”

Diova didn’t bother trying to hammer his way through Victorina’s shield, like he had with his previous opponent, and instead took advantage of Victorina’s distractedness to cast a full body shield of his own. Victorina finished hers just slightly ahead of Diova, and followed it up immediately with a Fire Bolt of her own. Diova’s shield snapped into place an instant before the bolt struck him, but this was a relatively small consolation. I’d been wondering what Victorina had been taking so long to cast, after all, she’d had the shield up already, what else could she be going for?

Water Elementals, that’s what.

Or at least, they looked like Water Elementals. There were two huge humanoid shapes, eight or so feet tall, and four feet wide, and both were comprised entirely of water. They surged towards Diova, and Victorina cast a pair of Water Jets. Diova retreated back slowly from the two hulking shapes, hands flying in a new spell. The Water Elementals seemed unable to move outside of the pool of water Victorina had created, but she prepared the ground for them with her pair of Water Jets.

Diova had caught on it seemed, and his completed spell turned out to be the same one that had launched him skywards initially. He didn’t get very far. The Water Elementals couldn’t walk outside of the pool, but their arms could reach outside of it just fine. Diova launched himself up and back, but one of the Water Elemental’s arms shot out, changing from a short tree trunk like protrusion, and into a wrist thick tendril of water fifty feet long.

It caught Diova by the ankle, and swung him back to the ground in a wide arc. The Elemental smashed him into the ground, hard enough that I thought I felt my teeth rattle, in the very centre of Victorina’s circle of water. The two Elementals surged from their position at the edge of the pool, and caught the still stunned Diova on the ground. Victorina wasn’t pulling her punches, and neither were her Elementals. The two of them pounded relentlessly on Diova’s shield, and I could see that the force of their blows was actually pushing Diova into the soft ground. He tried to lift his arms to cast a spell, but the Elementals hammered that arm back down.

Victorina cut off the Water Jets, and stood back some distance, while the Elementals tried to break down Diova’s shield. It was hard to hear over all of the splashing, but I thought I heard Diova start to chant something as the Elements continued their relentless pounding.

“Is the shield providing air as well?” I asked Halea, “The Elementals have pushed him well below the surface of that pool.”

“He’ll have whatever air was trapped inside of the shield when he switched to being impermeable to liquids. Not a lot, but it will be enough for a minute or two,” she replied, leaning forwards, “I’m just trying to figure out what that spell is he’s casting.”

Victorina noticed it first, when her next breath fogged the air. I caught on a moment later, as ice crystals started to form in the pool around him. Then it became a race, to see who would run out of energy first. Diova, who had to sustain both the shield, and his frost spell, or Victorina. Who had to provide the energy to keep the two Elementals together.

I had no idea what any of those spells might cost in energy, but I imagined that none of them could be cheap. Such a large scale temperature change was likely to be taxing, but then how could you even quantify the energy cost of creating even just one Elemental?

Diova seemed to be winning out though, and as he chanted the ice crystals grew and knit together around him. The ice even served to protect him, as the Elementals now had a second barrier between them and their target. They were getting sluggish though, the spreading ice seeming to sap their strength and speed. In an instant the ice around their feet was frozen, and the two Elementals found themselves locked in place, with ice spreading up towards their knees as they too started to freeze. Victorina was also caught in the ice, with the water around her feet freezing, trapping her in place.

The Elementals managed a few final strikes before they finally froze solid, but that quickly proved counterproductive. It hadn’t been enough to finally penetrate Diova’s shield, but it had been enough to ensure that the ice covering him was mostly shattered.

He sat up, pushing shards and sheets of ice off of himself, but seemed unable to stand since his legs were still trapped under the ice. His shield faltered a moment later, almost in the same instant as Victorina’s, and the two found themselves maybe ten feet from each other, almost completely immobilized, and probably without a drop of mana.

There was a beat, as they both took stock of their limited options, and then they set to it with a fervour. Both of them double-fisting Fire Bolts, of the weak sort that they could each cast without needing to tap their now empty mana reserves. Both of them kept up the stream of fire admirably, and both seemed able to concentrate on their spells despite the pain of the constant concussive blasts. In real terms the exchange was probably shorter than it felt to watch, or to take part in. Watching it, I was sure that they’d each hit the other at least fifty times, and they probably felt like they’d each taken a couple hundred magical punches in the face, but it couldn’t have been more than half a dozen in reality.

Victorina was the first to fall. Diova’s position had been awkward, but it had lent him some degree of protection, since Victorina had a smaller target to shoot at. The limited guidance that all projectile spells had didn’t help either, since from what I’d seen during the first round, the Mage needed to see their target for it to work. And after the first or so strike, both of them were firing blindly as they each had small explosions going off in their faces and throwing off their aim.

She crumpled forwards awkwardly, feet still trapped in the ice, and the gong rang to signal the end of the match.

Shit.

Training helps demystify all of that, knowledge is the best antidote to fear, and training grants that knowledge.”

This means that it’s fairly easy for a Mage to get a little flustered in combat, and to make the wrong decision, even if that Mage is quite clever otherwise. She got tunnel vision, she had what she thought was a decent solution, and when it didn’t work she didn’t try a different one, she just tried the same thing but with more effort behind it. It happened to Brodeu as well, do you know what I mean by that?” I asked.

And that’s Andrew’s strategy, his strategy isn’t acid or teleportation, those are just the tools he’s using to accomplish it. His strategy is to scare the hell out of his opponent so that they make mistakes, they seize on the first counter-strategy that they can think of, and they’re too flustered to reassess once it’s clear that it’s not the best solution. He’s amplifying the normal effect that combat has on people, especially untrained or less trained people. Brodeu didn’t want Andrew getting any closer, and in effect he was rushing to shoot him, when the best thing to do would have been to slow down, just a little bit. I never had to worry if an attack was too powerful for me to slow down or stop, when I was a good ten yards away when it went off. Quinn had always given me shit for not being a giant nerd like he was, a ‘dumb jock’ he’d said. Well he hadn’t done what I’d done, he hadn’t come up with as killer combo as I had. The game never mattered, and it didn’t matter if it was PC, PlayStation, or table top. Quinn always had to win. Dad always said that we should be patient with Quinn though. Dad said that Quinn was only like that because he wasn’t really good at anything else, and didn’t have really any friends, so he stayed inside and played videogames all day. Quinn liked to act like he was smarter than us, but really all he’d done is practice more, while the rest of us were busy doing real life stuff. Dad said that maybe joining the military would make Quinn more normal, but I guess that didn't really work out.

Well guess what Quinn? Now I’ve got it all. I’m stronger, more athletic, better looking, and I figured out magic stuff that you can’t even wrap your head around. You’re ‘smart’? Sure, sure Quinn. Pretty sure magic is about being smart, and the University even knows that I’m better at magic than you. Hell, I’ve even got my pick of any of the girls from the League, do you? No you damn well don’t, you’re too busy being Victorina’s bitch. Well guess what? My club leader kicked your club leader’s ass. And to top it all off, I’m Dad’s heir. Well isn’t that just perfect.

I wanted to get up and start running as soon as I’d fired it, but if I broke line of sight the orb wouldn’t be able to home in on it’s target, and I was counting on that to make up for any error in my aim.

She screamed, and tried to jump away from where the acid had hit her. It didn’t really work, and only made her look foolish as she slipped and went tumbling down the hill. I stood and broke into a run as soon as she tumbled out of sight, I had to catch her while the acid was still doing its work. It would stick around for a little while, but that didn’t mean that I had time to waste. ‘

It was easy to find her, even if all the hills looked the same, I just had to follow the whimpers and muted screams. I came up on her while she was still thrashing around, trying to rub the acid off onto the ground. The acid had hit her pretty hard, I had after all put a lot of power into the Acid Ball, and one side of her chest was bared where the acid had eaten her robes.

She really does look like a boy.

I smirked, and lifted a hand. It was just as I started casting Acid Jet, that the world went black.

Minki might possibly be your best friend… isn’t that a strange thought, and you’d better not fuck it up. Not like you did with Sila, not really sure how you messed up with Sila, but whatever you did, don’t do it again.

“Probably not,” Victorina replied, “But he can probably manage to cast that second shield he’s holding without using any mana at all. It’s a common strategy by the more defensively minded Mages. It will stop light projectile spells entirely, and at least slows down the more powerful ones.”

“Ah, it saves him from spending as much energy on the personal shield?” I asked, and Victorina nodded in reply.

Welp, turns out the MAC spell was that strong.

From what I could tell she hadn’t even put that much power behind it, it was more an attack to probe his defences than anything else. It was maybe two mana, used to propel four projectiles? It would have been directly comparable to four rounds fired from a rifle like an M16, which is something that essentially all modern rigid body armour would be able to stop with little trouble.

It cut right through both layers of shielding like they weren’t even there. Victorina sighed, “Baron Bronippo, Another one of Diova’s clubmates.”

“Uhh, are we supposed to let them win so Diova doesn’t get pissed off?” I asked, unsure.

“No, of course not,” Victorina replied tiredly, “But beating them this badly doesn’t really endear them to us, now does it.”

“I suppose not, on the other hand, we are kinda kicking ass here,” I grinned.

“You’re welcome,” Minki said quietly, and I laughed.

“Why did it go through the shield so easily though?” I asked, “I mean, the projectiles are moving faster than most elves will be able to imagine, but it’s still only so much energy behind them. If Halea had put ten times as much mana behind a Fireball or something similar, wouldn’t the shield have stopped it then?”

“It would have,” Victorina replied, “I imagine that the trouble is they’re using the wrong sort of shield, I just don’t know why. It seems obvious to me that the normal shield just won’t cut it, and Bronippo is smarter than that. He should have known better.”

“I don’t think so,” Minki said quietly, and almost apologetically, “I don’t think that anyone has any idea what the spell even does yet. They’re probably still trying to figure out what element the spell is based on, I don’t think they’ve even considered the possibility that the spell is used to propel a physical object. The projectiles move so fast that you can’t even see them, we know what the spell is because Quinn told us, they don’t have that advantage.”

Victorina nodded, “That would make sense, let’s just hope that Samala doesn’t figure it out before the fight.”

“I guess that the right sort of shield would stop the projectile?” I asked.

“Yes, there’s two main sorts of shields. You can have one built to stop magical attacks or similar mundane effects, or one built to stop physical attacks. Normally the physical shield is restricted to defending against uneducated men with sharp bits of metal, or Water Elementals,” she said bitterly, “But your spell has changed that.”

“Can you not run both at once?” I asked, “What about Diova’s shield?”

“You can, or rather, there’s a spell that combines the two shields into one. It’s expensive though, so most people don’t bother to add on that second layer. Besides, most of the things you defend against with a physical shield can be seen coming a long way off.”

“Alright,” I nodded, “Who’s Samala then?”

“Deputy Hierarch of The Order of The Claves, he’s actually been the favourite to win I believe,” Victorina explained.

“Deputy Hierarch?”

“A guild Hierarch is the leader of a guild, obviously, and is somewhere between a Count and a Duke. Each guild controls two counties, and all the people and resources that come with those lands. The deputy Hierarchs are about equivalent to Barons,” she clarified, “Though most of the time they don’t actually rule a city.”

“Well, I guess Halea’s not going to make many friends in The Order of The Claves when she takes this guy’s head off,” I said confidently.

Chapter 44

Quinn

Strictly speaking, she didn’t take his head off.

The beginning of the fight was very similar to the one with Bronippo, though Samala didn’t make the same mistakes that Bronippo had. I wasn’t sure if Andrew had gone and told Samala what I’d created, they were potential rivals after all, or if he was just hedging his bets, but when he cast his shields I saw that they were both the purplish colour of the combined Magical-Physical version. He also prepared a projectile spell, though this one was an Acid Ball, rather than a Lightning Bolt. Halea, just as in the previous fight, hopped her way across the arena from hilltop to hilltop, making directly for Samala’s starting position.

Just as last time Halea crested the hill and Samala launched the spell he’d held ready, and used his other hand to put his secondary shield between himself and Halea. Halea blocked it with a shield of her own, just as last time, and then cast the MAC spell at Samala. There was a crack as the tiny lead ball was accelerated past the speed of sound, and then two flashes of light, one from each of Samala’s shields. The secondary shield, the plane of force projected from his outstretched hand, snapped out of existence a moment later, but his full body shield prevented the projectile from getting to him.

And then they each did it again, Samala brought his secondary shield back up and threw an Acid Ball, only to be blocked by a shield cast by Halea, and then she cast MAC, which took down his secondary shield but was blocked by Samala’s primary shield. And then they did it again, and again, and again, for ages. Samala tried to manoeuvre a little for a better position, his spot at the bottom of the valley wasn’t great after all, but essentially they were just standing there slugging it out.

It seems kinda like one or both of them is making a massive strategic error here. I just have no idea who it is. Is it Halea, who is beating seemingly ineffectually on Samala’s shields? Or is it Samala, who is letting Halea drain his mana with every impact on his defences.

I had to remind myself that Samala, Bronippo, and all the others were in no way fools. A human born fifty thousand years before I was had essentially the same potential as a human born today, or at least, today on Earth. What they lacked were opportunities, and education. This was the same. The elves were not foolish, they just didn’t have anything to compare this spell to. They were trying to fit the spell into their model of how the world worked, when the spell was drawing upon concepts that they couldn’t yet conceive of.

Given time, the spell would become mundane. It would be taught alongside Fireball, Lighting Bolt, Acid Ball, and the others as another in the group of standard projectile spells. Just as Acid Ball’s would be used when you needed to disrupt concentration, or Lightning Bolt would be used to stun an opponent, MAC which still needs a catchier name would be the spell to use if you needed to counter an enemy’s shield spell.

Until then though, we were going to be hard as hell to beat.

It was probably four or five minutes into the mutual slugging match when I finally turned to Victorina and asked, “Is there something I’m missing here? It seems an awful lot like neither of them is really being very smart about this. One of them is going to bungle their defence eventually and get hit, and it seems like it could just as easily be Halea as it could be Samala.”

She leaned in a little, “You should give Halea more credit Quinn, I think she’s taking quite good advantage of Samala’s ignorance here.”

“Oh?”

“You’ve been watching as she casts your spell, you know that she’s not putting much mana into it, right?” She asked, and I nodded in reply, “Well Samala doesn’t know that, all he saw is what the spells done to everyone that’s been hit with it. She’s not even cast it with more than two mana over the course of this whole tournament, but every time it is cast and it hits, it’s usually enough to end the fight.”

“Alright,” I nodded slowly, “So she’s casting it without much power, probably even for free, but he thinks that there’s a lot of mana behind every shot. So, what, he thinks that he’s wearing her out?”

“Exactly,” Victorina confirmed, “And I bet that the effect that the spell is having on his shield is only reinforcing his incorrect assumption. If I had to guess, I’d say that each hit with the spell takes a pretty big chunk out of his shield. It’s meant for crossbow bolts, arrows, and rocks, not whatever this monstrous creation of yours is, and so the spell needs more energy to compensate for that. He’s used to the shield taking less mana to block an attack, than it took to cast the attack. You’ve created a spell that turns that relationship around.”

“So he knows that he’s haemorrhaging mana with every hit by Halea, but he thinks that ’s spending even more by blocking his Acid Balls and casting MAC,” I said, getting it finally, “The only question is how he’s lasted so long then. Seems like this has gone on for a while.”

“Samala is a deputy hierarch, which means he’s by no means a pauper. He’s probably got several mana stones to draw upon,” she explained.

“Does Halea have any?” I asked, “Though I’m guessing that Samala believes that she does.”

“Oh, maybe,” Victorina said, “But she’s probably not drawn on them very much. She’s really only spending mana to block the odd Acid Ball.”

“I guess we just need to wait then,” I said, leaning back in my seat.

Hell, even Uncle Walsh and his matchlocks would be trouble if shield spells respond poorly to low mass by high velocity projectiles. A musket ball from one of those won’t match even the one mana version of my MAC spell, but they’d be a damn sight faster than an arrow.

Shields in general seemed rather iffy though, it was the sort of thing that would take a hell of a lot of practice to get right. Not casting the spell itself mind you, that was the easy part. No, the trouble was knowing which one you needed. In the arena that was somewhat easier, since the answer was usually to cast both, but that wasn’t always true, and I wouldn’t always be in the arena. For each 1 mana put into it, you could block X amount of stuff. I had no idea what X was, but more mana meant more blockyness. The spell was limited in that you couldn’t put more energy into the shield after it was cast, and if you had enough energy to stop one and a half arrows, well that extra half an arrow’s worth of energy was essentially a waste since you’d still find yourself getting perforated.

The alternative was the full body shield that Samala was using, but it could also result in a massive wasting of energy, depending on the situation. It would automatically adapt to any incoming strike, and would draw exactly enough energy from the caster to stop the attack, which solved the problem of trying to estimate what it would take to stop an attack on the fly. The problem was that it also took energy to keep the shield in place. It wasn’t a lot, but it wasn’t zero either.

So the arithmetic came down to whether that additional energy expenditure was worth the additional benefits. It could entirely eliminate energy lost to overestimation, but on the other hand it was still a constant drain on your reserves. Was one more of the burden than the other? Well the answer would depend on the mage.

What it meant for Halea and Samala though, was that Samala was quickly running out of reserves, while Halea was relatively fresh. It only took another minute or so for those reserves to run dry, and Samala’s shield snapped off. He had completed the casting of Deflect just as Halea finished her super-charged MAC, and did his best to use it to fend off the incoming projectile.

It sort of worked.

He caught it early, which probably helped a great deal, but it wasn’t enough. He went down hard, his shoulder a bloody mess, and his arm landed a couple feet behind him in the dirt. The gong rang, signalling an end to the match, and to the tournament. Halea had won.

I really hope they’re not too sour about it if I run into them at the ball.

Chapter 45

Quinn

At least I don’t need to wear a tie.

The formal robes weren’t as short as most of the more regular wear robes I had, but still gave me plenty of room to move. Most men’s robes, along with most women’s robes, fell somewhere between ankle and mid-calf. The robes I wore now, as I inspected myself in the mirror, were knee length.

It wasn’t any spectacular fashion statement that I was making, or at least, that’s not what I was trying to do. The standard mage robes just looked too much like dresses to me, and wearing robes cut in the normal style would have just made me feel self-conscious. What I’d ordered instead for myself as an alternative looked more like a trench coat, in the case of the robes I was wearing now, or a hoodie, in the case of the robes I normally wore.
